UNHCR in COP14 plans to implement focused HIV programming in refugee camps in the Ethiopian regions of Gambella, Benishangul Gumuz, Tigray, Afar and Somali as well as in Addis Ababa where Urban refugees from more than 13 nationalities reside. In line with the geographic focusing of programs to maximize PEPFAR HIV investments, there will be more emphasis on higher HIV-prevalence regions such as Gambella where there are currently more than 90,000 refugees from South Sudan. Based on APR data, UNHCR will focus interventions based on the different characteristics of each refugee population. However, refugees have potential pre-disposing factors that could put them at risk that include; displacement, gender vulnerabilities, establishment of new sexual networks and loss of livelihoods. These factors can lead to sexual exploitation, abuse and other violations with HIV transmission implications in the long-term. The impact of stigma and the complexity of HIV programming in emergency settings are some of the obvious limitations hindering prevention efforts. Therefore, the UNHCR HIV programs will give more emphasis to high HIV prevalence regions and more focused programs in regions with relatively lower prevalence regions targeting at the major drivers of the epidemic including undiagnosed infection.
